15.answer: An SVM is a supervised learning algorithm. 	•	It tries to find a line/plane (hyperplane) that separates classes with the largest margin. 	•	It mainly uses the closest points called support vectors. 	•	It can be used for classification, and also for regression (SVR). 	•	With a kernel, it can handle non-linear data.

16.answer: An SVM is a supervised learning algorithm. 	•	It tries to find a line/plane (hyperplane) that separates classes with the largest margin. 	•	It mainly uses the closest points called support vectors. 	•	It can be used for classification, and also for regression (SVR). 	•	With a kernel, it can handle non-linear data.

18.answer: 1) Underfitting 	•	Model is too simple → can’t capture pattern. 	•	High bias. 	•	Train error high, and test error also high.  2) Overfitting 	•	Model is too complex → learns noise. 	•	High variance. 	•	Train error very low, but test error high.  3) The compromise 	•	Called the bias–variance trade-off. 	•	Goal: good generalization (balance complexity). 	•	Ways to control: regularization, cross-validation, early stopping, simpler model / more data.

19.answer: Relationship: Pattern recognition (PR) focuses on identifying regularities in data and assigning labels or categories to observations (e.g., classification). Machine learning (ML) provides the algorithmic framework to learn these decision rules/models from data. In practice, modern PR is largely implemented using ML methods, and the two fields strongly overlap.  Origins: Both PR and ML have roots in statistics and probability (e.g., Bayesian decision theory, estimation, hypothesis testing), signal processing (feature extraction, filtering), and early artificial intelligence. Classic PR emphasized pipelines such as preprocessing → feature extraction → classifier, while ML increasingly emphasized data-driven model learning and optimization.
